docs.lead_paragraph: Excessive weight gain in pregnancy can result in bigger-than-average babies who are prenatally programmed to become overweight children.

headline.seo: Children’s Sleep Plays Role in Weight Regulation
headline.print_headline: RISKS: Asleep, and Helping to Keep the Weight Off
headline.main: Risks: Asleep, and Helping to Keep the Weight Off

docs.lead_paragraph: Children under 5 who do not get at least 10 hours of sleep at night are almost twice as likely to be overweight or obese later in childhood, a new study reports.
docs.snippet: Children under 5 who do not get at least 10 hours of sleep at night are almost twice as likely to be overweight or obese later in childhood, a new study reports.

headline.main: In Feast of Data on BPA Plastic, No Final Answer

docs.abstract: Scientists are split on effects of plastic products made using bisphenol-A, or BPA; consumer fears, often stoked by marketing, have led to wide-range of BPA-free products; research has shown BPA to produce harmful effects in rats and mice, but scientists disagree about whether chemical can impact humans, particularly babies and fetuses; National Institutes of Health hopes to standardize testing and align data to produce measurable and comparable results; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: The research has been going on for more than 10 years. Studies number in the hundreds. Millions of dollars have been spent. But government health officials still cannot decide whether the chemical bisphenol-A, or BPA, a component of some plastics, is safe. The substance lines most food and drink cans, and is used to make hard, clear plastic bottles, containers and countless other products. Nearly everyone is exposed to it. Concerns about BPA stem from studies in lab animals and cell cultures showing it can mimic the hormone estrogen. It is considered an ''endocrine disruptor,'' a term applied to chemicals that can act like hormones. But whether it does any harm in people is unclear.
docs.snippet: The research has been going on for more than 10 years. Studies number in the hundreds. Millions of dollars have been spent. But government health officials still cannot decide whether the chemical bisphenol-A, or BPA, a component of some plastics, is...

headline.seo: Child’s Ordeal Shows Dangers of Antipsychotic Drugs
headline.print_headline: Child’s Ordeal Reveals Risks Of Psychiatric Drugs in Young
headline.main: Child’s Ordeal Shows Risks of Psychosis Drugs for Young

docs.lead_paragraph: Powerful drugs are given to young children despite a lack of study on how they affect development.
docs.snippet: Powerful drugs are given to young children despite a lack of study on how they affect development.

headline.main: Child's Ordeal Reveals Risks Of Psychiatric Drugs in Young

docs.abstract: More than 500,000 children and adolescents in America are now taking antipsychotic drugs and their use is growing not only among older teenagers, when schizophrenia is believed to emerge, but also among tens of thousands of preschoolers; some psychiatric experts say that trend they find increasingly worrisome is ready prescription-writing by doctors of more potent drugs like Vyvanse to treat extremely young children whose conditions rarely require such measures; Columbia University study found doubling of rate of prescribing antipsychotic drugs for privately insured 2- to 5-year-olds from 2000 to 2007; only 40 percent of them had received proper mental health assessment, violating standards from American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry; many doctors say prescribing drugs for younger and younger children may pose grave risks to development; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: OPELOUSAS, La. -- At 18 months, Kyle Warren started taking a daily antipsychotic drug on the orders of a pediatrician trying to quell the boy's severe temper tantrums. Thus began a troubled toddler's journey from one doctor to another, from one diagnosis to another, involving even more drugs. Autism, bipolar disorder, hyperactivity, insomnia, oppositional defiant disorder. The boy's daily pill regimen multiplied: the antipsychotic Risperdal, the antidepressant Prozac, two sleeping medicines and one for attention-deficit disorder. All by the time he was 3.
